channel.title: XploR Eos IDE
channel.description: Recent content on XploR Eos IDE

item.title: Installation
item.description:
Installation

  • Download the .deb file: Visit the official website and download the .deb file for the desktop version.

  • Install the .deb file using the Terminal:

    • Open a terminal and navigate to the directory containing the .deb file
    • Run the following command to install the package:
    sudo dpkg -i <path-to-deb-file>/XploREosIDE.deb

  • Launch the IDE: After the installation completes, you can start the IDE by searching for it in the application menu or running the command in the terminal:

item.title: System Requirements
item.description:
System requirements

Hardware

Memory Disk space
Minimum 8GB x86_64 multi-core
Recommended 16GB+ x86_64 multi-core (8+ threads)
It is highly recommended to use a system that goes beyond the suggested requirements. Although XploR Eos IDE can operate on a system that meets the minimum specifications, the performance is likely to be subpar.

Operating System

Linux

The IDE currently supports only Linux, with the following distributions being available:

item.title: Creating and debugging a FreeRTOS application
item.description:
This project referred to in this chapter is called Blinky. This application prints Blink text. Through the debug session, users can examine RTOS objects such as Task and Queue. The application can also be built and run on QEMU emulator.

To build, run and debug Blinky applications with QEMU emulator, please install the freertos-virt-qemu-blinky-example components first.

Click the Install Dependencies button, select freertos-virt-qemu-blinky-example template and click the Install button.

item.title: Creating and debugging a baremetal application on DE2-115 FPGA
item.description:
Prerequisites

  • DE2-115 FPGA board.
  • USB Blaster and UART cable for programming and debugging.
  • Necessary drivers installed for communication with the hardware.

Install template

Click the Install Dependencies button, select baremetal-neorv32-de2115-helloworld-example template and click the Install button.

item.title: Managing Projects
item.description:
Concepts

This section provides an overview of workspaces and projects and some features support users working more conveniently.

  • Workspaces: Includes the created projects and additional folders, providing a unified and organized environment for efficient development.
  • Projects: Initialized from a template, contains all necessary information and resources to develop a specific program.
  • Xplorer: Navigates, opens, and manages files and folders within your project.

Workspaces

A “workspace” consists of one or more folders opened within the File Navigator. It uses a *.xplor-workspace JSON file to define and list the folders included in itself.

item.title: Building Projects
item.description:
Xplor Eos IDE supports building projects via the user interface. This section explains how to configure this feature to enhance your development workflow.

Build Configurations

A build configuration is the blueprint for compiling your project. Our templates predefine this configuration and store it in a tasks.json file, located within the .theia folder in your workspace. Configuration tasks contain fields to save build profile information. The build configurations can be changed through changing the task configurations in the tasks.json file.

item.title: Launching a Debug Session
item.description:
Xplor IDE support for debug projects currently in Xplorer, this section will guide you on how to start debugging in Xplorer, for more complete information about debugging features, debugging steps as well as debug configuration, please see in the next section.

Launching a Debug Session

There are several ways to start a debug session in XploR Eos IDE:

First of all, ensure the project is built. For building instructions, see Building the Project section.

item.title: Debugging the Application
item.description:
XploR Eos IDE provides an integrated Debug View, where users can start, stop, and control the debugging process, view variables, and monitor the call stack. Additionally, multiple data views give a comprehensive overview by revealing the status of different subsystems of the target. This section outlines some of these views and features.

When you will switch from the Xplorer to the Debug view in the Side Bar, displaying the default arrangement of views as shown below. The Call Stack provides information on the current program. In the source code view, the program is usually displayed as halted at the beginning of the main() function (though this may vary depending on the loaded program). Below the Threads, Call Stack, Variables, Watch, Breakpoints are also available.

item.title: Debug Configuration
item.description:
A debug configuration is a set of properties defined in a launch.json file. It specifies how the debugger interacts with the program being debugged and includes the necessary parameters for a debugging session.

The IDE typically generates a default launch.json file automatically when a project is created using our template. the launch.json file is saved in the .theia folder within your workspace directory.

You can easily access the launch.json file by clicking the Open launch.json button in the Debug View.

item.title: FreeRTOS QEMU
item.description:
This chapter covers the basics flow from getting a QEMU FreeRTOS template to debugging it and checking RTOS Object when debugging.

Components Prerequisites

  • freertos-virt-qemu-blinky-example: Blinky FreeRTOS Project for XploR Eos IDE
  • freertos-virt-qemu-heap-example: Generic Heap FreeRTOS Project for XploR Eos IDE
  • freertos-virt-qemu-timer-example: Timer FreeRTOS Project for XploR Eos IDE

Working flow

  1. Click the Install dependencies button, choose FreeRTOS in the Type field and click the Apply filter button.

item.title: GNU C/C++ Helloworld
item.description:
This chapter covers the basics of C/C++ embedded projects including creating, building, running, and debugging baremetal applications. The project referred to in this chapter is called “Hello World.” This application prints “Hello World” text and runs a simple for-loop as a simple demonstration. The application can also be built and run on QEMU emulator.

Components Prerequisites

  • baremetal-virt-qemu-helloworld-example: Hello World C Baremetal Project for running on QEMU
  • baremetal-virt-qemu-helloworld-cpp-example: Hello World C++ Baremetal Project for running on QEMU

To build, run and debug GNU Helloworld applications, please make sure that all above components are installed. Please refer to Install a Template for more information about installing component.

item.title: LLVM Helloworld
item.description:
This chapter covers the basics of C embedded projects including creating, building, running, and debugging baremetal applications. The project referred to in this chapter is called “Hello World.” This application prints “Hello World” text and runs a simple for-loop as a simple demonstration. The application can also be built and run on QEMU emulator.

Components Prerequisites

  • baremetal-virt-qemu-helloworld-llvm-example: Hello World Baremetal (LLVM) Project for running on QEMU

To build, run and debug LLVM Helloworld applications, please make sure that all above components are installed. Please refer to Install a Template for more information about installing component.

item.title: Bitfile Programming
item.description:
Bitfile Programming

This feature allows you to detect the connected FPGA board, core, vendor, bitfile. It streamlines the process of programming an FPGA device by automating the detection of necessary components and providing a user-friendly interface for initating programming operations.

1. FPGA Setup

Before proceeding, ensure that all required components (e.g., baremetal-neorv32-de2115-helloworld-example) and drivers for your FPGA board and JTAG cable are installed correctly. This includes drivers for the JTAG interface and any FPGA-specific toolchains such as Quartus or Vivado.

item.title: XploR Labs
item.description:
XploR Labs is an extension that enables users to connect to their cloud workspaces and access them remotely from a local machine.

Step to connect:

  1. Click to XploR Labs icon in the Activity Bar.

  1. Select the login button and enter the cloud server URL. (The IDE supports all cloud systems based on Coder Server.)

  1. The IDE will open a browser to retrieve a session token for authentication. Copy the token and paste it into the IDE.

item.title: Open Remote SSH Connection
item.description:
XploR Eos IDE makes it easy to connect to a remote machine via SSH and work seamlessly as if you were on your local machine. Here’s how to get started:

  • Open a Remote Window:

    Click on the Open a Remote Window button located at the bottom-left corner of the IDE. From the menu, select Connect Current Window to Host….

  • Enter Your Remote Connection Details:

    A dialog will appear where you can input the necessary information to connect to your remote machine:

item.title: Easy documentation with Docsy
item.description:
This is a typical blog post that includes images.

The front matter specifies the date of the blog post, its title, a short description that will be displayed on the blog landing page, and its author.

Including images

Here’s an image (featured-sunset-get.png) that includes a byline and a caption.
